title: Friday, 29th September, 2017
bodyHTML:

SpaceX CEO Elon Musk unveiled revised plans to travel to the Moon and Mars at a space industry conference today, but he ended his talk with a pretty incredible promise: using that same interplanetary rocket system for long distance travel on Earth. Musk showed a demonstration of the idea on stage, claiming that it will allow passengers to take “most long distance trips” in just 30 minutes, and go “anywhere on Earth in under an hour” for around the same price of an economy airline ticket.

Okay, so the idea here is the Florence speech kicked actual Brexit down the hill for a while so in response the market's now baking in nothing unexpected.

ah, ok. ta

BE11:21am

Or as Nomura phrases it, Florence "sets the stage for a much longer period between the Brexit vote and the Brexit actuality than could have been taken as the base case before. We believe it stretches it to such a long time that it will become very difficult for rates and FX markets to trade with a ‘Brexit handicap’ in their asset pricing. This suggests pricing in a ‘proper’ BoE MPC hiking cycle and all the implications of that for GBP and UK rates."

Danger

11:22 am
BE11:22am

We have, of course, been in a similar position before. At almost every stage since the end
of the recession following the GFC, financial markets have expected the BoE to imminently
tighten monetary policy (Figure 3). Over the past decade, expectations for central bank
action have changed globally – notably, the speed with which central banks are expected
to take back highly accommodative policies has been reduced significantly, as has the
terminal point official rates are expected to reach in the cycle (Figures 3 and 4).
This would not be the first time that the BoE under its current leadership has raised the
spectre of interest rate normalisation. Recall Governor Carney’s remarks in his Mansion
House speech of June 2014: “there’s already great speculation about the exact timing of
the first rate hike... it could happen sooner than markets currently expect” (at the time
the markets had been anticipating a hike as soon as early in 2015). Those comments,
among others, earned the governor the moniker of an “unreliable boyfriend”, according to
one member of the Treasury Select Committee at the time. More recently, the Bank’s
chief economist, Andy Haldane, said in a speech back in June that “I do think that
beginning the process of withdrawing some of the incremental stimulus provided last
August would be prudent moving into the second half of the year.”

BE11:23am

So this time it might actually happen because the data are moving in the right way. That's the upshot.

BE11:23am

..... And spinning back to the rubbish Q2.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Have HSBC there, to save me typing.

BE11:25am

Q2 GDP growth was confirmed at 0.3% q-o-q (Chart 1). Q1 growth was revised up by 0.1ppt, to
0.3% q-o-q. But small downward revisions to growth in 2016 mean year-on-year growth has been revised down from 1.7% to 1.5% y-o-y.
The second estimates of the Q2 expenditure mix showed consumption growth revised up from
0.1% to 0.2% q-o-q. Total investment was revised down marginally from 0.7% to 0.6% q-o-q,
although business investment was revised up from 0.0% to 0.5% q-o-q. Export growth was revised up from 0.7% to 1.7% q-o-q, while imports growth was revised down from 0.7% to 0.2% q-o-q. Net trade contributed +0.4ppts to Q2 growth (0.0ppts in the previous estimate). Offsetting the
upward revisions to net exports and consumption growth, government consumption growth was
revised down from 0.6% to 0.1% q-o-q.
Regarding the near term outlook, probably the most significant news was a disappointing services growth estimate for July. Growth came in at -0.2% m-o-m (consensus +0.1%). And 3m/3m growth came in 0.5% (consensus 0.7%) (Chart 2).
Today's print contains substantial revisions to the national accounts as part of the ONS's 'Blue
Book' exercise. Big picture, the pattern of GDP growth is little changed.
But there were considerable revisions to the income side of the accounts. The most significant was an upward revision to household income. This was driven by the ONS improving its accounting
for the increasing number of self-employed people setting up companies and paying themselves via dividends. The upward revision to household (dividend) income means the household saving ratio has been revised up materially, but it is still shown to have fallen sharply in the early part of this year (Chart 3).

BE11:25am

Sorry for the lack of charts. Have another wall of text instead.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Implications:
Having grown by a lacklustre 0.3% q-o-q in Q1 and Q2, the weak July services print raises questions
about how much of a GDP improvement we will see in Q3. Granted, the 0.5% 3m/3m growth in services is a slightly improvement on growth seen earlier this year, but we had been expecting a more solid outturn. Meanwhile, manufacturing growth remains fairly soggy and construction output is still falling.
The risks to our Q3 GDP forecast for 0.5% q-o-q growth now lie to the downside. It's not all bad news though. The revisions to the Q3 expenditure mix offer some scope for encouragement. Annual business investment growth was revised up from 0.0% to 2.5% y-o-y. And net exports are now shown to have made a large positive contribution to growth, in Q2 at least. There is a possibility here that the economy is showing at least a partial rebalancing towards exports in response to last year's sterling depreciation. We also take some comfort from the upward revision to the household saving ratio, which might offer households more wiggle room to run down their savings as the inflation squeeze continues to weigh on real incomes.
But we would warn against getting too excited about the robustness of household spending. The recent sharp decline in the saving ratio, to record lows, has not been revised away -- it still looks stretched by historical standards. And households are still facing the two headwinds of the inflation squeeze and Brexit uncertainty. These headwinds, and the signal we draw from the soft July services print, mean we think the economy is still not out of the woods.

BE11:26am

Despite today's disappointing news, to services growth in particular, a November Bank Rate hike still looks in prospect. With the unemployment rate at a record low of 4.3%, and with MPC members, including Governor Mark Carney just this morning, having strongly signalled the prospect of a rate hike 'in the coming months', it will take more than this for the MPC to back down. Our view is that the MPC will raise rates by 25bps in November and next May. But over the longer term, with wages (we think) set to remain sluggish and Brexit uncertainties still in play, we think the MPC will take pause after that.

BE11:26am

Yes, raise then pause. Market's wrong here. And I don't say that very often.

Here's Peel Hunt.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Interims below expectations but are prepared on an ‘going-concern’ basis. Construction provisions unchanged at £845m but a £200m Services provision announced today (largely non-cash. FY2018 ND guidance increased to £825m-£850m (from £775m-£800m). Facilities extended by £140m to £1.6bn and covenants expect to be met. IFRS 15 expected to impact reserves by £125m-£150m. Outlook is cautious and we reduce our underlying Dec’17 PBT from £135m (cons £136m) to £110m, to give EPS of 20.9p from 25.0p. We still believe Carillion needs greater than £500m from fresh equity and/or from potential disposals (indicated £300m today). Shares trading on 2.5x Dec’18 EPS but av debt adjusted EV/EBITDA of 5.5x. Whilst there are many good businesses within Carillion, we remain wary given the many balance sheet uncertainties.

BE11:35am

And Stifel.

BE11:36am

Much to take in. The contract review is complete with an additional £200m provision in
Support Services, but minimal cash impact. The group expects to remain within covenants
at the full-year before disposals, which are now expected to raise £300m. Leverage
reduction to 1.0-1.5x by the end of 2018 cannot be achieved through self-help with “all
options” on the table. Full-year underlying operating profit is now expected to c.20%
lower, with a cost savings programme being implemented. We place our target price and
estimates under review.

What happens next? In the short-term, Carillion has indicated that full year earnings will be lower than current market expectations, which we see as underlying PBT of £140 million (Bloomberg). We are 6% lower at £132 million. The order book, which stands at £16.0 billion, ‘underpins’ the outlook. Carillion suggests its total revenue visibility is 95%. The transformation of Carillion is judged to be a ‘three to five year journey’ that requires a cultural shift. It remains to be seen if an equity raise is seen as necessary to de-risk the balance sheet and no doubt this will be the main preoccupation of the market over the next few months.

BE11:44am

Our answer on Advertising Agencies: As shown in today’s separate AdWatch note, we now believe the way to play agencies is based on momentum. We would happily miss the first 10% in a rally to get more certainty. Agencies are very cheap (9% FCF yield) and forecasts for the world’s top advertisers suggest that their revenues should re-
accelerate, which has been positive for the agencies in the past (strong correlation).
However, we believe that the degree of forecasting error for 2018E is too high to be
positive today.

Our answer on free-to-air broadcasters: We believe in a bottom up approach, favouring the names with the best diversification strategy as we broadly agree with investors’ structural concerns. We are Overweight ITV, M6 and Pro7Sat1 for this
reason, but they also offer short-term market momentum (ITV and M6) and potential market share gains (Pro7Sat1).

11:44 am

BE11:45am

They reckon ITV's cheap though.

BE11:45am

ITV: We upgrade ITV to Overweight and raise our price target to 200p from 190p. We have
four reasons to upgrade ITV. 1) Advertising is improving in the UK with media buyers
calling September to November flat. This means ITV should deliver a Q3 at the top of their
guidance (“ITV Family NAR is forecast to be down around 4% in Q3 with July down 5%,
August down 4%, September flat to down 5%”). If December is also flat (likely with the
three previous months flat) then FY17E NAR should decline 4.5% (our new forecasts)
versus consensus at -5.8%. 2) While it is early to call 2018E, media buyers are revising up their thinking to flat from negative and some are mentioning a flow back to television from
digital. Consequently, we see little risks of downgrade on 2018E in the coming months (consensus at -0.3%). 3) 1H18E comps are easy, implying that ITV could post positive advertising numbers in Q1 and Q2 which will lessen structural worries (advertising quarterly progression in 2017 should be -9%, -7%, -4% and 0-1%). 4) valuation gives little credit to ITV for their non-television businesses

The UK is at a point of inflection with a doubling in revenues anticipated for the first half. Local Property Expert numbers have increased to 640, up from 448 at FY17 and ahead of our full year estimate of 605. Whilst c.100 of these have only traded for two months, it shows Purplebricks’ continued focus on growth in its existing markets despite management’s increasing focus on the US.

11:59 am

Net cash of £64.9m at 30 August 2017 is sufficient in our view to continue to fund growth in the existing markets and to cover the earmarked US$50m investment spend over the next 2 years for the US. With the UK EBITDA positive and Australia forecast for FY19e, we see the business as well funded.

We view the re-affirming of guidance as positive, particularly given that the initial guidance came in as unexpected at FY17e. We expect minimal changes to consensus.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Caz remains positive-ish.

BE12:06pm

The housebuilders are up c.30% year to date, driven by earnings upgrades and improved confidence in the outlook. We still think the sector is cheap, on 8.7x 2018E P/E and yielding c.6%, particularly given that we still see upside risk to estimates, driven primarily by a combination of conservative guidance and better land buying conditions of recent years being reflected in earnings. We see limited risk from either a rate rise or a change to the Help to Buy scheme. Our top picks are generally in the small cap space, with BWY and RDW trading at a discount, despite high growth and positive earnings momentum.

BE12:06pm

Stock picks: While we can easily argue the sector is cheap across the board, the strongest performers year-to-date have been those companies delivering upgrades. On that basis, we feel most comfortable in the small caps, particularly Bellway and Redrow, where we continue to view guidance as conservative relative to recent growth levels. Despite this, the stocks trade on sub 7x P/E one year forward. We still think there are upgrades in PSN (OW) and see upside potential to the TW/ dividend, despite a current 8% yield (OW). We are still OW BKG, with the view 2019 upgrades are coming. We downgrade Countryside to Neutral (from Overweight) following a period of strong performance, and remain Neutral on Bovis and Crest, although we see upside risk to both, given that we think Bovis could see further upgrades and Crest looks cheap on any metric, if we get more comfortable that guidance is achievable.

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Strong performance driven by upgrades, which should continue: The housebuilders are up c.30% year to date, with upgrades having driven about half of the performance. Our estimates today are c.15% higher than at the start of the year and c.6% higher than even our pre-Brexit numbers, driven in our view, by slightly better market conditions than expected even back then, better operational performance, and a continued degree of prudence in guidance. We still see scope for these factors to continue driving upgrades. Much of this year’s performance is about regaining last year’s underperformance. Since the start of 2016, stocks have still slightly underperformed the FTSE 250.

BE11:36am

Our target price of 114p is derived from our sum-of-the-parts valuation. This applies
appropriate comparative EV/EBITA ratios to the group’s construction and support
services activities, adds our valuation of the PPP portfolio and deducts obligations to
stakeholders, including the pension deficit.
